standfirst: Delaware police say single-engine aircraft lost contact with air traffic controllers before crashing in river near New Jersey
headline: Small plane crashes in Delaware River as police rescue occupants

standfirst: Seven-year-old Haadi Akhtar was found unconscious about 40m from his family in 'white out' conditions but later died
headline: Boy dies at Mount Buller after being buried under snow

standfirst: Judge is expected to receive reports by panel of experts who assessed whether athlete has anxiety disorder
headline: Oscar Pistorius to return to dock after psychiatric tests

standfirst: Country wants film about attempt to assassinate Kim Jong-un banned and says failure to stop its release will be 'act of war'
headline: North Korea threatens 'merciless' response over Seth Rogen film

standfirst: Man believed to have fired at least one shot before police arrived
headline: Armed man arrested after being locked in Queensland house with baby

standfirst: Police say eight people hospitalised, including one in critical condition, after an early morning shooting on famous street
headline: New Orleans shooting injures nine on Bourbon Street

standfirst: Rainbow-clad members of the LGBT community gather in Mexico City at the capital's annual gay pride parade on Saturday. Participants say the celebration is important as they call for respect from the rest of the country. According to activists, there have been many reports of homphobic attacks outside the relatively liberal capital
headline: Mexicans celebrate at the annual gay pride parade - video

standfirst: Government wants to build 440 walls along coastline, but some residents believe a concrete fortress is not the answer
headline: Tsunami-proof 'Great Wall of Japan' divides villagers

standfirst: Foreign minister says the horological initiative is intended to help people find their indigenous roots
headline: Bolivia turns back the clock in bid to rediscover identity and 'southernness'

standfirst: Rescuers continue to look for survivors and pull bodies out of the rubble after an 11-storey building collapsed on Saturday near Chennai, southern India. The tower was still being built and fell after workers went inside to shelter from the rain during monsoon season. Building collapses are common in India due to lax regulations and substandard construction
headline: Dozens believed to be trapped after under-construction building collapses in India - video

standfirst: Tower on outskirts of Chennai was under construction when it crumbled, killing at least 11
headline: Dozens trapped as building collapses during monsoon rains in India

standfirst: Anthony Albanese says taxpayers funding profits, as party signals willingness to reconsider Qantas ownership provisions
headline: Labor slams Sydney airport maintenance after blackout

standfirst: Prison service confirms device landed in Wheatfield jail. One inmate understood to have found and ingested drugs
headline: Remote-control helicopter containing drugs crashes into Irish prison yard

standfirst: Gunmen launch long-range attack on aircraft as it lands in Peshawar, leaving one person dead and two injured
headline: Passenger killed in gun attack on Pakistani plane

standfirst: On a street corner by the river, the shots that sparked the first world war were fired. Finally, residents are hoping to lay to rest the ghosts of past conflicts
headline: Sarajevo: city commemorates end to 'a century of conflict', but divisions still run deep

standfirst: Ministers agree to support the star rating system pulled down by Fiona Nash’s chief of staff who had links to junk food companies
headline: Healthy food rating website could be reinstated within weeks

standfirst: Gordon Stevenson and Peter Fraser speak to the media after being married in a ceremony at the consulate of the United Kingdom in Sydney. Their marriage is the first same-sex marriage to take place in a UK consulate anywhere in the world, but it will not be recognised by the Australian government
headline: First UK consulate gay marriage takes place in Sydney - video

standfirst: A filmed message intended for asylum seekers has emerged, featuring immigration minister Scott Morrison. In the film, which was originally intended to be shown to asylum seekers in detention centres run by Australia, Morrison urges detainees to return home or face a 'very, very long time' in detention
headline: Scott Morrison: asylum seekers must go home or face 'a very, very long time' in detention – video

headline: Morrison film telling asylum seekers to go home screened in detention centres

headline: Port Moresby under police lockdown as crowds call for PM to quit

• Shots fired shortly after 5am at party 'related' to award

standfirst: Campaign team says Ghani has beaten rival by more than 1.3m votes, but Abdullah Abdullah withdraws because of alleged fraud
headline: Ashraf Ghani claims Afghan presidential election victory

standfirst: Emergency services hack away at the walls of a cliff gap in eastern China after a 75-year-old tourist fell into the crevice. The man fell into a gap around 30 metres long and just 20-50cm wide. Luckily the tourist's cries for help were heard by passers-by and he was rescued within two hours
headline: 75-year-old tourist rescued after being trapped in narrow cliff gap in China - video

standfirst: Call to professionalise party's federal fundraising after Icac focus on donations to New South Wales branch
headline: Outgoing Liberal president suggests corporate membership

standfirst: Argentinian president's popularity falls as corruption charges against Amado Boudou, and inflation and debt tarnish her government

standfirst: North Koreans march through the streets of Pyongyang with banners to commemorate the 64th anniversary of the beginning of the Korean war. State media shows crowds shouting slogans such as 'Down with the US aggressor'. The war started in 1950 when North Korean troops launched a surprise attack into South Korea
headline: North Koreans hold a rally to mark 64 years since the start of the Korean war - video

standfirst: The former speaker has pleaded not guilty to charges of dishonestly using a taxpayer-funded Cabcharge card
headline: Peter Slipper wants fraud charges dismissed on mental health grounds

standfirst: Australia's deputy prime minister Warren Truss says it is 'highly, highly likely' missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 was on autopilot before it went missing. The search area for the plane, which disappeared on 8 March with 239 people on board, has been shifted further south in the Indian ocean. Two vessels are currently mapping the sea floor along the arc of the search area
headline: Flight MH370: new search area announced in Indian ocean - video

standfirst: Renowned corruption fighter says Liberal National party has embarked on 'destructive' first term, undermining the judiciary and interfering in the electoral system
headline: Tony Fitzgerald tears into Queensland government for abuse of power

standfirst: Republican senator Thad Cochran narrowly sees off his Tea Party rival, Chris McDaniel, in the Mississippi primary on Tuesday. Cochran says the win reflects a consensus among voters about the need for 'more and better jobs for Mississippi workers'. The result is a relief for the Republican party after a long and at times turbulent primary season

standfirst: A man in Tokyo set himself alight at a busy intersection on Sunday in an apparent protest against changes made by the Japanese prime minister. Shinzo Abe is shifting the country's defence policy by ending the pacifist constitution. Witnesses say the man was protesting against this before he self-immolated. He is currently in hospital
headline: Japanese man sets himself on fire in apparent anti-government protest - video report

standfirst: A Jordanian court ruled on Thursday that international terror suspect Abu Qatada is not guilty of terrorism offences relating to an alleged 1998 bomb plot. The UK sent the radical Islamist cleric back to Amman in 2013 on the promise that the court would not use evidence obtained by torture. Qatada will receive the verdict for a second set of charges later in the year
headline: Radical Islamist cleric Abu Qatada cleared of terrorism offences in Jordan - video

standfirst: Events are held in Sarajevo and Visegrad on Saturday one hundred years after Gavrilo Princip shot and killed the heir to the Austro-Hungarian throne, Archduke Franz Ferdinand, which sparked the first world war. Protesters in the Bosnian capital are angry that so much money has been spent on centenary celebrations after the country recently experienced devastating floods
headline: Bosnia-Herzegovina marks centenary of Archduke Franz Ferdinand's assassination in Sarajevo - video

standfirst: Meriam Ibrahim, the Christian Sudanese woman detained when she tried to travel to the US after being released from death row, is released on Thursday for a second time. standfirst: Andrew Laming becomes the second politician to take to the Guardian Australia whiteboard to help explain the controversial 2014 Australian federal budget. Laming breaks down what he calls an unsustainable level of debt while explaining the carbon tax, fuel rebate, commonwealth scholarships, co-payments and cuts to the ABC and SBS.

standfirst: The latest stunt by flamboyant Chinese businessman Chen Guangbiao backfired on Wednesday after he promised 200 homeless people $300 each ... but then failed to pay up. Chen, famed for his attention-grabbing philanthropy, had promised to donate the money over a free lunch at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. Unfortunately the cash never materialised
headline: Chinese businessman Chen Guangbiao promises homeless New Yorkers $300 each … but fails to pay – video

standfirst: Freedom Summer, a program that brought mostly northern white college students to Mississippi to register black voters, turns 50. Three young civil rights workers were slain by Ku Klux Klan members on a country road in Neshoba County prompting a massive FBI search for them and their killers. The bodies of Andrew Goodman, James Chaney and Michael Schwerner were found two months later buried in an earthen dam
headline: Mississippi Freedom Summer: 50 years on – in pictures

standfirst: Clive Palmer has announced that his Palmer United party  senators will vote to repeal the carbon tax if savings are passed on to the average Australian, and will support an emissions trading scheme. In a joint press conference with former US presidential candidate Al Gore, Palmer said his party would move to amend the repeal legislation to force producers to pass on savings to consumers.

standfirst: Unprecedented numbers are risking their lives to reach Europe, and local authorities in coastal communities where they land are struggling to cope. Lizzy Davies reports from Catania while photographer Massimo Sestini accompanied the Italian navy on its rescue missions earlier this month, offering a rare up-close glimpse of the men, women and children who make the dangerous trip to start a new life

standfirst: Devices purported to identify and cure hepatitis and HIV set to be put to use have been delayed citing 'further testing'

standfirst: Iraqis from a predominantly-Christian town south of Mosul flee from fighting between Kurdish forces and Isis militants. The UN's refugee agency says as many as 10,000 people have fled the Christian communities of Qaraqosh since violence broke out. Isis captured Mosul, Iraq's second-largest city, in a sweep of northern Iraq in early June
headline: Thousands of Iraqi Christians flee from fighting between Isis and Kurdish forces - video

standfirst: Human Rights Watch says it has identified the sites of mass executions in Iraq earlier this month after comparing satellite images to photos released by Isis militants. Analysis shows the executions of between 160 and 190 men took place in a field near a former palace of Saddam Hussein. Recent satellite images have shown no bodies, which may have been buried or moved elsewhere
headline: Human Rights Watch identifies Isis execution sites based on satellite images - video

standfirst: Footage of young children carrying rifles with Isis fighters has sparked concerns the militant Islamist group is recruiting young people. The video shows two boys brandishing the guns as part of a convoy in which Isis paraded weapons and vehicles seized from the Iraqi army in Mosul. Human rights groups say the rebels have recruited children as young as 14 in the past
headline: Iraq: gun-toting children paraded in Isis convoy - video

standfirst: Residents of Baquba, an hour from Baghdad, are on the frontline of a sectarian showdown that is fast becoming another civil war

standfirst: Deadline moves to 10pm on Friday in apparent attempt to kickstart negotiations with rebels in east of country
headline: Ukraine extends ceasefire by 12 hours

standfirst: Ukrainians gather around the presidential administration building and in Kiev's Independence Square on Sunday to demonstrate against the president's extension of a ceasefire in the east of the country. Petro Poroshenko extended the truce by three days after returning from signing a free trade deal in Brussels. Fighting has continued in eastern Ukraine over the last week despite the ceasefire
headline: Ukrainians protest in Kiev against ceasefire in the east of the country - video

standfirst: Exhibition at French museum to tell story of 1914 battle which forced German retreat and prevented enemy from taking Paris

headline: Isis onslaught in Iraq claims terrible toll of victims on both sides of divide

standfirst: Prime minister denies coordination with Assad as Iraqi forces raid Tikrit and Kurdish leader makes symbolic visit to Kirkuk
headline: Isis: Maliki hails Syrian air raids in Iraq as leaving both states 'winners'

standfirst: Air strikes may spell end of what has often looked like a mutually beneficial relationship between Syrian regime and jihadists
headline: Assad and Maliki unite against common enemy Isis

standfirst: A bad day for Europe, says isolated and bitter David Cameron as commission chief nominated
headline: Britain closer to EU exit after Jean-Claude Juncker vote

standfirst: The bandwagon that appointed Juncker has been rolling since at least 2009
headline: The EU's 'democratic' system that elected a president nobody wants

standfirst: Shadow chancellor calls efforts to stop Juncker's appointment as European commission president a 'catastrophe for Britain'
headline: Cameron's attempt to block Juncker was 'cack-handed', says Ed Balls

standfirst: European leaders including David Cameron and German chancellor Angela Merkel attend a ceremony on Thursday in Ypres, Belgium, to commemorate 100 years since the first world war. The ceremony kicked off a two-day EU summit during which Cameron faces defeat over the appointment of the next president of the European commission
headline: Cameron and European leaders attend first world war ceremony in Ypres - video

standfirst: German chancellor promises review of nomination process as Sweden's Reinfeldt says post-vote paper allows EU flexibility
headline: Merkel offers Cameron olive branch after Juncker vote

standfirst: Kiev to sign association agreement with European Union, which Viktor Yanukovych backed away from in November
headline: Ukraine set to sign EU pact that sparked revolution

standfirst: EU heads of state met in Belgium this week, nearly all of them support Juncker's presidency
headline: Unlike David Cameron, Gavrilo Princip had fellow plotters

standfirst: Ukraine's president Petro Poroshenko signs a free-trade agreement with the EU and fellow former Soviet republics Georgia and Moldova on Friday. The former Ukrainian president's failure to sign the agreement last year led to his ousting after months of protests in Kiev. The agreement has angered Russia, with one adviser to Vladimir Putin calling Ukrainian leaders 'Nazis'
headline: Ukraine signs a free-trade agreement with Europe in a step towards the west - video

standfirst: Gay rights activists say aim was to repeat lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender rally targeted by homophobes last year
headline: Georgian pro-Russia group 'planned fake pride march to scupper EU deal'

standfirst: Employers' leader John Cridland makes case for continued European Union membership after Cameron's Juncker defeat
headline: EU exit will harm UK, says leading British industry group

standfirst: A survey shows more than half are satisfied with their lives and think positively about their employment prospects
headline: Germans reject their joyless image to become Europe's optimists

standfirst: Dentist and his wife sue British Airways for booking them tickets to Caribbean island rather than Spanish city 6,000 miles away
headline: Alleged BA mixup sent US couple to Grenada instead of Granada

standfirst: Islamic Federation of Catalonia says Qatari emir is backing €2.2bn plan for mosque on site of disused Plaza Monumental
headline: Barcelona bullfighting ring may become Europe's largest mosque

standfirst: From Cameron and Coulson to European privacy, insecticides and new miniature mammals – a roundup of the week's news
headline: 10 things we learned this week

standfirst: Prime minister suffers humiliating defeat as EU leaders vote 26-2 in favour of nomination for European commission president
headline: David Cameron loses Jean-Claude Juncker vote

standfirst: European leaders arrive at a meeting in Brussels on Friday ahead of an expected decision on a nominee for the president of the European Commission. The vote is mired in controversy as David Cameron stands against his fellow leaders in not supporting the favourite for the role, Luxembourg's Jean-Claude Juncker. Cameron believes Juncker will limit the powers of EU nations and increase the powers of Brussels
headline: David Cameron continues opposition of Jean-Claude Juncker at EU summit - video
Taking stock after Cameron's failed EU tactics

standfirst: Signs EU leaders will offer overwhelming support to the former Luxembourg leader, despite UK prime minister's objections
headline: Cameron warns EU leaders over Juncker appointment

standfirst: Prime minister says 'railroading through' candidate for European commission will have grave impact on British public opinion
headline: Cameron tells EU it may live to regret Jean-Claude Juncker appointment

standfirst: Press encouraged Angela Merkel to back Luxembourger's European commission candidacy, but he is now facing scrutiny
headline: German media go cool on Jean-Claude Juncker over speaking engagements

standfirst: Prime minister's lonely bid to remake the EU to his liking has ended in disaster, and strengthened the hand of Eurosceptics
headline: Humiliating defeat for David Cameron pushes Britain towards EU exit

standfirst: Prime minister attacks the frontrunner for the leadership, who he says has been dedicated to increasing the power of Brussels
headline: Juncker is wrong person for European commission job, says David Cameron
